name: bleep
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
a short, high sound made by a machine, especially if it is repeated: He wears a wristwatch with an irritating bleep.
US informal used when someone is speaking, to avoid saying a swear word: Where the bleep are my keys?

You can also find related words, phrases, and synonyms in the topics:
Linguistics: sounds used as interjections
[ I ] (of a machine) to make a short, high sound: I heard his alarm clock bleeping this morning.
[ T ] UK (US beep) to call someone, for example a doctor, by sending a signal to a bleeper that they carry: Bleep me if his condition worsens. bleep something (out)
(on TV, etc.) to replace a swear word with an electronic sound so that people will not hear the swear word and be offended: Oops! Can you bleep that?
See more

Communications - messaging
used to avoid saying a swear word, for example when you are angry or surprised: Oh, bleep. Why did I do that? She said, "Holy bleep! That's my mum!"
More examplesFewer examplesWe lost the money. Bleep!Holy bleep! That is scary.I went, oh, bleep, bleep, bleep.

Add to word list
Add to word list
a short, continuous electronic sound: Cell phones now play pop tunes rather than making bleeps.
to make a short, continuous electronic sound
If an offensive word on television or radio is bleeped or bleeped out, it is replaced with a short, continuous electronic sound: [ T ] Portions of the program were bleeped before the broadcast
